fields.headline: Sport news in brief
fields.bodyText: Golf: McIlroy will bounce back, says captain McGinley Europe's Ryder Cup captain, Paul McGinley, believes the former world No1 Rory McIlroy will recover from his collapse in form to be an integral member of his 12-man team to take on the USA at Gleneagles in a year's time. "There hasn't been a player in the history of the game who has not gone through peaks and troughs," McGinley said. "Rory has pretty much had a vertical upwards trajectory, so it was only a matter of time before he had a bit of a spiral. But there is no doubt he will come back up again." When it was put to McGinley that McIlroy's trough has proved rather a deep one, the Dubliner was unmoved. "Tom Watson went through one," added McGinley. "Jack Nicklaus had a long period of time between winning one major and the next. It comes and goes, as some people come out of it very quickly. Just look at what's happened to Henrik Stenson. Rory is such a good player and he has so much drive. He will not be sitting back on his laurels; he will be practising hard. It will come back and things in his head will just click into place." Ewan Murray Moto GP: Márquez on pole No7 The Championship leader, Eur, set a track record to claim pole position at the Aragon MotoGP. The defending champion Jorge Lorenzo starts today's race from second, followed by Márquez's Honda team-mate and last year's winner in Aragon, Dani Pedrosa. The 20-year-old Spaniard beat Casey Stoner's fastest time in 2011 with a late flying lap of 1:47.804 at the 5km circuit. It was Márquez's seventh pole in his first season in MotoGP. Lorenzo's Yamaha team-mate Valentino Rossi was fourth. Britain's Cal Crutchlow had a frustrating day as he could only manage seventh for Tech 3 Yamaha, with his team-mate Bradley Smith lining up alongside him in eighth. AP Cycling: Kenny strikes gold The Olympic champion Jason Kenny claimed gold in the men's sprint finals on day four of the British Cycling National Track Championships in Manchester. Kenny held off the challenge of Peter Mitchell with Matthew Crampton defeating Craig MacLean in the bronze medal contest. Corinne Hall took victory in the women's scratch race ahead of Laura Trott.PA
